There's one thing that makes me wonder about super senses:
I'm overly sensitive to some smells and that doesn't just mean that I can smell things from far further distances and for far longer than normal humans, but it also means that something that smells for you strongly makes me sick, or causes me to sneeze like mad... Having a million times more sensitive nose would be an utter nightmare! Even now, I can barely tolerate standing in the same room with some humans and one caused my sneeze reflex whenever she got close. Adding a factor 1000 or more would make me sneeze in the entire building.
Similarly, how can it be that e.g. cat who have far better ears than us can sit on a loudspeaker?

Actually the Mantis shrimp may not even be able to see the same range of spectrum as we do. They have all those extra photoreceptors because each photoreceptor respond to a specific light signal, while our photoreceptors respond to a spectrum.

This means, each photoreceptor is catered for a specific color which narrows their capability to see other colors that they may not have the photoreceptor for. Our photoreceptors meanwhile can mix and match signals creating a blend that increases the range of colors we see.

This video is great, like any other on this channel, BUT:

I think that the discussion on the sense of smell that was made for bears is misleading (just like almost any source you can find about "smell").

My or other animal's nose doesn't have superpower which allow it to smell something from distance. The nose smells what enters it, no matter what; just like eyes see the photons that hit the retina. Therefore, saying that the bear's nose can sense something from kilometers doesn't tell me much about how strong it is, because there could be just a nice wind which throws the smelly molecules in its face. I think that giving numbers in terms of "minimum concentration of smelly molecules in the air that they can smell" for bears, dogs, humans, would really be more useful.


Great series nonetheless.

Fun fact, humans actually DO have a super sense of smell, it's just VERY specifically keyed in to something.... odd. You know that earthy smell just after it rains, the one that lingers for a bit and smells so nice? You know the smell of freshly turned soil? What you're smelling is a chemical called geosmin. It's released by bacteria in the soil as they die and, over time, builds up in the soil. When it rains, the surface soil is disturbed and this chemical is released. The human nose is so specially refined to smell geosmin that we can actually pick it up better than sharks can smell blood! We can smell as little as 15 NANOGRAMS per liter of the stuff, or 15 parts per TRILLION!

What we don't understand so well.... is why.
Fleshy whiskers.

false/exaggerated bloating.
